description: From Middle French métaphore, from Latin metaphora, from Ancient Greek μεταφορά (metaphorá), from μεταφέρω (metaphérō, “I transfer, apply”), from μετά (metá, “with, across, after”) + φέρω (phérō, “I bear, carry”).

entries.meaning: (uncountable, rhetoric) The use of a word or phrase to refer to something other than its literal meaning, invoking an implicit similarity between the thing described and what is denoted by the word or phrase.
examples: Coordinate term: simile (when the similarity is made explicit by the words like or as)

entries.meaning: (countable, rhetoric) A word or phrase used in such implied comparison.
examples: A Metaphor may be changed into a Simile, and also into plain language, containing neither metaphor nor simile. Thus:
Metaphor. — Idleness is the rust of the soul.
Simile. — As rust is to iron, so is idleness to the soul, taking away its strength and power of resistance.
Plain. — Idleness takes away from the soul its strength and power of resistance.

entries.meaning: (countable, graphical user interface) The use of an everyday object or concept to represent an underlying facet of the computer and thus aid users in performing tasks.

verbs.description: metaphor (third-person singular simple present metaphors, present participle metaphoring, simple past and past participle metaphored)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To describe by means of a metaphor.
